item.title: Talk:ColdFusion/Flex Connectivity:Release Notes
item.description:
New page

The instructions mention uninstalling beta 1 prior to installing beta 2
"If you previously installed ColdFusion/Flex Connectivity beta 1 (also known as the ColdFusion/Flex Connectivity Beta), uninstall it according to the procedures outlined in the Uninstalling ColdFusion/Flex Connectivity beta 2 section that follows."

In my experience, the uninstall directions did not apply.
http://labs.macromedia.com/wiki/index.php/ColdFusion/Flex_Connectivity:Release_Notes#Uninstalling_ColdFusion.2FFlex_Connectivity_Beta_2

DK
item.dc:creator: dougk

item.title: Flex
item.description:
/* The Flash Platform: Expanding the Richness of Rich Internet Applications */

Revision as of 17:34, 21 Mar 2006 Current revision
Line 87: Line 87:
Flash Player is the most widely deployed audio and video player on the market. It allows video elements to be seamlessly integrated into the surrounding content or application, such as triggering video cue point events in your RIA. It supports progressive download of short-form video files and integrates with Flash Media Server 2.0 for streaming more interactive, higher quality, long-form video. Flash Player is the most widely deployed audio and video player on the market. It allows video elements to be seamlessly integrated into the surrounding content or application, such as triggering video cue point events in your RIA. It supports progressive download of short-form video files and integrates with Flash Media Server 2.0 for streaming more interactive, higher quality, long-form video.
-The community has leveraged these capabilities to create rich Internet applications that break down the silos that exist today between applications and rich media. Instead of having their applications launch a separate media player—thereby creating a discontinuous experience—Flex developers can truly integrate video into their applications' user interface and workflow. For example, training videos can navigate and highlight particular user interface elements of your application and your application can cue specific portions of a video to play based on a user's actions. Flash video and audio streams can be incorporated into Flex 2.0 applications by using [http://www.macromedia.com/go/fms | Flash Media Server 2] or [http://www.macromedia.com/go/fvss | Flash Video Streaming Service], a hosted service for delivering large-scale Flash Video deployments developed by leading CDN (Content Delivery Network) partners in conjunction with Adobe. +The community has leveraged these capabilities to create rich Internet applications that break down the silos that exist today between applications and rich media. Instead of having their applications launch a separate media player—thereby creating a discontinuous experience—Flex developers can truly integrate video into their applications' user interface and workflow. For example, training videos can navigate and highlight particular user interface elements of your application and your application can cue specific portions of a video to play based on a user's actions. Flash video and audio streams can be incorporated into Flex 2.0 applications by using [http://www.macromedia.com/go/fms Flash Media Server 2] or [http://www.macromedia.com/go/fvss Flash Video Streaming Service], a hosted service for delivering large-scale Flash Video deployments developed by leading CDN (Content Delivery Network) partners in conjunction with Adobe.
-Lastly, now that the merger of Adobe and Macromedia is complete, you can expect to see interesting new innovations to work their way into the Flex product line. As we look forward, some of the areas we are investigating include support for real-time collaboration, improved designer-developer workflow, and greater support for offline applications and documents. Look for more on our future direction on Adobe Labs in the coming months. +Lastly, now that the merger of Adobe and Macromedia is complete, you can expect to see interesting new innovations to work their way into the Flex product line. As we look forward, some of the areas we are investigating include support for real-time collaboration, improved designer-developer workflow, and greater support for offline applications and documents. Look for more on our future direction on Adobe Labs in the coming months.
===A Call for Community Involvement=== ===A Call for Community Involvement===
By now you've seen a high-level overview of the Flex 2.0 product line, including Flash Player 8.5, the Flex Framework, Flex Builder, and Flex Data Services. Our goal for the Flex 2.0 product line is to provide the developer community with a great platform for delivering the best application experiences to their customers. By now you've seen a high-level overview of the Flex 2.0 product line, including Flash Player 8.5, the Flex Framework, Flex Builder, and Flex Data Services. Our goal for the Flex 2.0 product line is to provide the developer community with a great platform for delivering the best application experiences to their customers.
-We have made the prerelease versions of Flex 2.0 available so the developer community at large would have an opportunity to have an early look at our direction, and to provide feedback. On behalf of the Flex product teams, I encourage you to visit [http://labs.adobe.com | Adobe Labs], download our beta, and get involved. If you’re a ColdFusion developer, be sure to download the additional ColdFusion/Flex Connectivity beta 2 updates as well. You can subscribe to the [http://www.macromedia.com/go/labs_rss/ | RSS Feed] to ensure you stay up to date and discuss your ideas and questions with other developers on the [http://www.macromedia.com/cfusion/webforums/forum/index.cfm?forumid=72 | Adobe Labs Forums]. +We have made the prerelease versions of Flex 2.0 available so the developer community at large would have an opportunity to have an early look at our direction, and to provide feedback. On behalf of the Flex product teams, I encourage you to visit [http://labs.adobe.com Adobe Labs], download our beta, and get involved. If you’re a ColdFusion developer, be sure to download the additional ColdFusion/Flex Connectivity beta 2 updates as well. You can subscribe to the [http://www.macromedia.com/go/labs_rss/ RSS Feed] to ensure you stay up to date and discuss your ideas and questions with other developers on the [http://www.macromedia.com/cfusion/webforums/forum/index.cfm?forumid=72 Adobe Labs Forums].
To help make your initial experience with the beta a productive one, we continue to provide a series of sample applications, tutorials, and other resources you can walk though before venturing "off road.” To help make your initial experience with the beta a productive one, we continue to provide a series of sample applications, tutorials, and other resources you can walk though before venturing "off road.”
-When you’ve seen what’s possible with Flex 2.0, please tell us what you think. We look forward to collaborating with you to build a set of products that enables you to change the face of Internet applications. +When you’ve seen what’s possible with Flex 2.0, please tell us what you think. We look forward to collaborating with you to build a set of products that enables you to change the face of Internet applications.

-''Note that this means certain APIs, such as createEmptyMovieClip() and createTextField(), are gone. In order to create a new TextField you use "new TextField()" instead of "createTextField()" '' - that sucks. why don't you keep createTextField() that now actually does "new TextField()", when called? you can't just throw away APIs in each and every AS version. how on Earth someone is supposed to maintain large code, if you change APIs every day?+One constant thing require is change. No matter in what technology the application is developed over the time if change does not occur the application will exhaust.
 + 
 +Hat's off to the entire Adobe and Macromedia community to introduce a new revolutionary into flash platform capabilities. First time in my life i can exhibit myself as a Flash Object oriented Programmer to the entire world.

item.title: Flex:Product Line Overview
item.description:
Revision as of 02:02, 21 Mar 2006 Current revision
Line 1: Line 1:
=Flex 2.0 Product Line Overview= =Flex 2.0 Product Line Overview=
-Flex delivers a complete solution for building rich and engaging web-based applications based on Adobe’s ubiquitous Flash Player. Flex 2.0 provides a comprehensive, integrated set of tools and technology enabling developers to build and deploy scalable Rich Internet Applications (RIA), including a powerful client runtime, programming model, development environment, and advanced data services. Flex supports common design patterns, works with existing development and deployment technologies, and provides the benefits of a modern, standards-based language. >> [[Flex | Read the full introduction to Flex 2.0]]+Flex delivers a complete solution for building rich and engaging web-based applications based on Adobe’s ubiquitous Flash Player. Flex 2.0 provides a comprehensive, integrated set of tools and technology enabling developers to build and deploy scalable rich Internet applications (RIA), including a powerful client runtime, programming model, development environment, and advanced data services. Flex supports common design patterns, works with existing development and deployment technologies, and provides the benefits of a modern, standards-based language. >> [[Flex | Read the full introduction to Flex 2.0]]
-==Flex Framework 2.0 – The essential building blocks for creating RIAs==+==Flex Framework & SDK – The essential building blocks for creating RIAs==
-The Flex Framework sets the foundation by providing a rich class library that includes the MXML and ActionScript 3.0 languages, base classes, user interface components and command-line tools for compiling and debugging applications. Flex 2.0 applications run in the Flash Player 8.5 client runtime, and can be deployed with or without Flex Enterprise Services, depending on application requirements. >> [[Flex_Framework | More info on the Flex Framework 2.0]]+The Flex framework sets the foundation by providing a rich class library that includes the MXML and ActionScript 3.0 languages, base classes, user interface components and command-line tools for compiling and debugging applications. Flex 2.0 applications run in the Flash Player 8.5 client runtime, and can be deployed with or without Flex Data Services, depending on application requirements. >> [[Flex_Framework | More info on the Flex framework]]
-'''*New* - Free SDK''' - Along with beta 1 we are announcing that the Flex Framework will be made available free of charge through the Flex Software Development Kit. >> [[Flex:SDK_Announcement | Read more about the Free SDK]]+'''*New* - Free SDK''' - Along with beta 1 we are announcing that the Flex framework will be made available free of charge through the Flex Software Development Kit. >> [[Flex:SDK_Announcement | Read more about the Free SDK]]
==Flex Builder 2.0 – A powerful development tool for building RIAs== ==Flex Builder 2.0 – A powerful development tool for building RIAs==
-Starting with Flex Builder, a brand-new IDE based on the Eclipse open source IDE framework, developers can quickly and easily design and build an engaging application leveraging the Flex Framework. >> [[Flex_Builder | More info on Flex Builder 2.0]]+Starting with Flex Builder, a brand-new IDE based on the Eclipse open source IDE framework, developers can quickly and easily design and build an engaging application leveraging the Flex framework. >> [[Flex_Builder | More info on Flex Builder 2.0]]
-==Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 – Reliable, high performance enterprise data connectivity==+==Flex Data Services 2.0 – Reliable, high performance enterprise data connectivity==
-Flex Enterprise Services add an important data interaction layer for rich applications enabling developers to become more productive while simultaneously allowing them to deal with the increasingly more complex needs of enterprise application development. >> [[Flex_Enterprise_Services | More info on Flex Enterprise Services 2.0]]+Flex Data Services add an important data interaction layer for rich applications enabling developers to become more productive while simultaneously allowing them to deal with the increasingly more complex needs of enterprise application development. >> [[Flex_Enterprise_Services | More info on Flex Data Services 2.0]]
-==Flex Charting Components 2.0 – Extensible components for advanced data visualization==+==Flex Charting 2.0 – Extensible components for advanced data visualization==
-Adding rich, high quality charting and data visualization is fast and easy when you use the Flex Charting Components. Line 1: Line 1:
-== RPC Services in Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 ==+== RPC Services in Flex Data Services 2.0 ==
''by Peter Farland, Senior Software Developer for Flex'' ''by Peter Farland, Senior Software Developer for Flex''
-The Flex 2.0 product line provides developers with several important changes to the way they can build and manage service-oriented rich Internet applications (RIAs). Although the changes in Flex packaging make it possible to build and deploy Flex applications with or without a server-side component, new capabilities in Flex Enterprise Services make it more valuable than ever. This article provides an overview of the new capabilities in Flex Enterprise Services 2.0, with a particular focus on differences between remote procedure call (RPC) services in Flex 1.5 and the latest version of Flex.+The Flex 2.0 product line provides developers with several important changes to the way they can build and manage service-oriented rich Internet applications (RIAs). Although the changes in Flex packaging make it possible to build and deploy Flex applications with or without a server-side component, new capabilities in Flex Data Services make it more valuable than ever. This article provides an overview of the new capabilities in Flex Data Services 2.0, with a particular focus on differences between remote procedure call (RPC) services in Flex 1.5 and the latest version of Flex.
-Flex 1.5 provides three APIs for making asynchronous calls to remote procedures through the <code>RemoteObject</code>, <code>HTTPService</code>, and <code>WebService</code> MXML tags. These services are known as RPC services and developers use them to build applications with a service-oriented architecture (SOA). Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 continues to provide these RPC services and introduces two new data services, which introduce new capabilities and a new programming model. All services are based on a common messaging architecture powered by a new version of ActionScript (ActionScript 3.0). This document describes the differences between the Flex 1.5 and Flex 2.0, and how Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 RPC services take advantage of these improvements.+Flex 1.5 provides three APIs for making asynchronous calls to remote procedures through the <code>RemoteObject</code>, <code>HTTPService</code>, and <code>WebService</code> MXML tags. These services are known as RPC services and developers use them to build applications with a service-oriented architecture (SOA). Flex Data Services 2.0 continues to provide these RPC services and introduces two new data services, which introduce new capabilities and a new programming model. All services are based on a common messaging architecture powered by a new version of ActionScript (ActionScript 3.0). This document describes the differences between the Flex 1.5 and Flex 2.0, and how Flex Data Services 2.0 RPC services take advantage of these improvements.
=== RPC Services and the Messaging Architecture === === RPC Services and the Messaging Architecture ===
Line 14: Line 14:
In Flex 1.5, a developer uses MXML tags to connect to RPC services. Several attributes are specified, such as the service name, the endpoint to which the request should be sent, and so forth. Each RPC service in Flex 1.5 makes use of different technologies, so configuration options and terminology differ between each service. For example, a <code>RemoteObject</code> tag specifies named or unnamed sources and connects to an Action Message Format (AMF) gateway, whereas <code>HTTPService</code> and <code>WebService</code> tags use named services or raw URLs and connect to an HTTP proxy using text-based query parameters or XML. In Flex 1.5, a developer uses MXML tags to connect to RPC services. Several attributes are specified, such as the service name, the endpoint to which the request should be sent, and so forth. Each RPC service in Flex 1.5 makes use of different technologies, so configuration options and terminology differ between each service. For example, a <code>RemoteObject</code> tag specifies named or unnamed sources and connects to an Action Message Format (AMF) gateway, whereas <code>HTTPService</code> and <code>WebService</code> tags use named services or raw URLs and connect to an HTTP proxy using text-based query parameters or XML.
-Flex 2.0 introduces several enhancements to this model that both make the model more consistent across different channels and offer greater flexibility to developers. On the client side, developers can use either MXML tags or pure ActionScript APIs to declare service connections. If the connection is client-side only, the URI for the service is specified as a parameter. If the connection takes advantage of Flex Enterprise Services, developers specify a logical <i>destination</i> associated with the desired service. Services represent various distinct capabilities, such as mediated web service calls or messaging integration. On the server, all destinations are configured through configuration files. A destination includes information about the endpoint to which a destination connects, the various messaging options that are used for all connections, as well as the channel that is used for communication. Channels represent a communication mechanism, typically specifying the protocol and a few options, such as whether the channel uses polling and the desired polling interval.+Flex 2.0 introduces several enhancements to this model that both make the model more consistent across different channels and offer greater flexibility to developers. On the client side, developers can use either MXML tags or pure ActionScript APIs to declare service connections. If the connection is client-side only, the URI for the service is specified as a parameter. If the connection takes advantage of Flex Data Services, developers specify a logical <i>destination</i> associated with the desired service. Services represent various distinct capabilities, such as mediated web service calls or messaging integration. On the server, all destinations are configured through configuration files. A destination includes information about the endpoint to which a destination connects, the various messaging options that are used for all connections, as well as the channel that is used for communication. Channels represent a communication mechanism, typically specifying the protocol and a few options, such as whether the channel uses polling and the desired polling interval.
All communication with the various services provided is mediated by a common message broker that directs messages to the appropriate service. The type of message and the destination selected are used by the message broker to select the appropriate service and to ensure that the service can handle the message. <code>RemoteObject</code> messages are routed to the Remoting Service, and <code>HTTPService</code> and <code>WebService</code> messages are routed to the Proxy Service. All communication with the various services provided is mediated by a common message broker that directs messages to the appropriate service. The type of message and the destination selected are used by the message broker to select the appropriate service and to ensure that the service can handle the message. <code>RemoteObject</code> messages are routed to the Remoting Service, and <code>HTTPService</code> and <code>WebService</code> messages are routed to the Proxy Service.

There isn’t a dedicated channel for <code>RemoteObjec</code>t; requests to the Remoting Service can be made over any channel. There isn’t a dedicated channel for <code>RemoteObjec</code>t; requests to the Remoting Service can be made over any channel.

=== New Features in RPC Services === === New Features in RPC Services ===
-The Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 messaging framework includes several new quality-of-service features that help make RPC service requests robust. First, each channel checks that it can communicate successfully with the server before sending any requests. Second, the developer can specify multiple channels for each endpoint, making configuration more flexible and enabling failover if the first channel is not available. The messaging framework also supports clustered environments, so RPC services can take advantage of redundant environments to provide robust services.+The Flex Data Services 2.0 messaging framework includes several new quality-of-service features that help make RPC service requests robust. First, each channel checks that it can communicate successfully with the server before sending any requests. Second, the developer can specify multiple channels for each endpoint, making configuration more flexible and enabling failover if the first channel is not available. The messaging framework also supports clustered environments, so RPC services can take advantage of redundant environments to provide robust services.
-Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 also provides a number of capabilities to improve the maintainability of applications. A services-specific configuration file lets developers add and remove destinations to services, configure channel endpoints, control access to services through security settings, define clusters for robust applications, and fine-tune logging to assist in debugging. The new configuration format also allows the developer to add new channels, services, adapters, login-commands, and logging targets as technology requirements change.+Flex Data Services 2.0 also provides a number of capabilities to improve the maintainability of applications. A services-specific configuration file lets developers add and remove destinations to services, configure channel endpoints, control access to services through security settings, define clusters for robust applications, and fine-tune logging to assist in debugging. The new configuration format also allows the developer to add new channels, services, adapters, login-commands, and logging targets as technology requirements change.
=== RPC Services Configuration === === RPC Services Configuration ===
Line 85: Line 85:
<small>'''Code example 2''' – General structure of Flex 1.5 configuration file, flex-config.xml</small> <small>'''Code example 2''' – General structure of Flex 1.5 configuration file, flex-config.xml</small>
-In Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 a separate configuration file, flex-services.xml, contains services-specific configuration. The three services-related sections from Flex 1.5 were removed from flex-config.xml, however, compiler-specific configuration settings remain in this file. Other web-tier configuration settings, such as caching and Flash Player detection, are in the flex-server-config.xml file. The Flex 1.5 gateway-config.xml file is no longer used. The new, common flex-services.xml file contains all relevant gateway features and applies the settings to all services.+In Flex Data Services 2.0 a separate configuration file, flex-services.xml, contains services-specific configuration. The three services-related sections from Flex 1.5 were removed from flex-config.xml, however, compiler-specific configuration settings remain in this file. Other web-tier configuration settings, such as caching and Flash Player detection, are in the flex-server-config.xml file. The Flex 1.5 gateway-config.xml file is no longer used. The new, common flex-services.xml file contains all relevant gateway features and applies the settings to all services.
The flex-services.xml configuration file lets developers include individual service definitions from external files. This helps isolate service-specific destinations and reduce the size of the main services configuration file, which allows easy access to common sections such as security, channels, and logging settings. The flex-services.xml configuration file lets developers include individual service definitions from external files. This helps isolate service-specific destinations and reduce the size of the main services configuration file, which allows easy access to common sections such as security, channels, and logging settings.

</services-config> </services-config>

-The flex-services.xml configuration file is required at compile time if the Flex application uses of Flex Enterprise Services. In the case of RPC services, this applies to all applications that use <code>RemoteObject</code> or proxy-based <code>WebService</code> or <code>HTTPService</code>.+The flex-services.xml configuration file is required at compile time if the Flex application uses of Flex Data Services. In the case of RPC services, this applies to all applications that use <code>RemoteObject</code> or proxy-based <code>WebService</code> or <code>HTTPService</code>.
The mxmlc compiler can point to the services configuration file by using the flex-config.xml file or command-line switches. The services configuration information is necessary at compile time because code must be generated to instruct the client which channels should be used for each service destination. The mxmlc compiler can point to the services configuration file by using the flex-config.xml file or command-line switches. The services configuration information is necessary at compile time because code must be generated to instruct the client which channels should be used for each service destination.

mxmlc --load-config=flex-config.xml --services=flex-services.xml MyApp.mxml mxmlc --load-config=flex-config.xml --services=flex-services.xml MyApp.mxml

* A new client logging library is included with Flex 2.0 in the <code>mx.logging</code> package. All services report information using this client logging API. The developer can specify the level of log events and filter the category of events. The developer can enable a logging target to view the information in a particular location. The most commonly used target is the <code>TraceTarget</code> (from the <code>mx.logging.targets</code> package), which reports information using the <code>flash.util.trace()</code> function. The debug version of the Flash Player outputs trace information to the flashlog.txt file in the user directory. * A new client logging library is included with Flex 2.0 in the <code>mx.logging</code> package. The developer can enable a logging target to view the information in a particular location. === Using Channels with RPC Services === === Using Channels with RPC Services ===
-A channel is responsible for transporting a message from the client to an endpoint on the message broker. The protocol used to transport the message is specific to the channel. A channel must also be able to support the data types of the client, namely types used in Flex applications that use ActionScript 3.0. A channel consists of a client implementation to serialize requests and deserialize responses, and a server implementation at the endpoint to deserialize requests and serialize responses. Flex Enterprise Services 2.0 ships with several channels to support the various requirements of services-based applications.+A channel is responsible for transporting a message from the client to an endpoint on the message broker. The protocol used to transport the message is specific to the channel. A channel must also be able to support the data types of the client, namely types used in Flex applications that use ActionScript 3.0. A channel consists of a client implementation to serialize requests and deserialize responses, and a server implementation at the endpoint to deserialize requests and serialize responses. Flex Data Services 2.0 ships with several channels to support the various requirements of services-based applications.
==== AMF Channel ==== ==== AMF Channel ====

==== mx.collections.ArrayCollection ==== ==== mx.collections.ArrayCollection ====
-Collections are used extensively throughout Flex 2.0. They provide an event framework for an Array to dispatch the correct events so that changes to the structure of the collection are reflected in Flex Components (especially UI Components) and vice versa. Flex Enterprise Services now maps client <code>mx.collections.ArrayCollection</code> instances to <code>java.util.ArrayList</code> on the server, and server-side <code>java.util.List</code> implementations map to <code>mx.collections.ArrayCollection</code> on the client. If a native client <code>Array</code> is desired in responses from the server then native Java Arrays (e.g. <code>java.lang.Object[]</code>) can be returned. Also note that client ActionScript <code>Arrays</code> are deserialized on the server as native <code>java.lang.Object[]</code> arrays.+Collections are used extensively throughout Flex 2.0. They provide an event framework for an Array to dispatch the correct events so that changes to the structure of the collection are reflected in Flex Components (especially UI Components) and vice versa. Flex Data Services now maps client <code>mx.collections.ArrayCollection</code> instances to <code>java.util.ArrayList</code> on the server, and server-side <code>java.util.List</code> implementations map to <code>mx.collections.ArrayCollection</code> on the client. If a native client <code>Array</code> is desired in responses from the server then native Java Arrays (e.g. <code>java.lang.Object[]</code>) can be returned. Also note that client ActionScript <code>Arrays</code> are deserialized on the server as native <code>java.lang.Object[]</code> arrays.
<b>Note:</b> <code>mx.collections.ArrayCollection</code> implements <code>flash.util.IExternalizable</code>. As such this type is not yet supported by the HTTPChannel. <b>Note:</b> <code>mx.collections.ArrayCollection</code> implements <code>flash.util.IExternalizable</code>. As such this type is not yet supported by the HTTPChannel.

item.title: Flex Enterprise Services:resources:articles:refactoring rpc
item.description:
Revision as of 01:46, 21 Mar 2006 Current revision
Line 1: Line 1:
-==Refactoring Flex Applications from RPC Style Data Management to Data Services==+==Refactoring Flex Applications from RPC Style Data Management to Data Management Services==
''by James Ward, Technical Evangelist for Flex'' ''by James Ward, Technical Evangelist for Flex''
Line 5: Line 5:
'''Introduction''' '''Introduction'''
-One of the most exciting new features of Flex Enterprise Services (FES) is the ability to easily manage data synchronization between Flex clients and backend services and data. In Flex applications a version of the application data exists on the client tier in a structured, meaningful way. This allows data manipulation to be performed on the client tier, but it requires that the changes to that data be synchronized with back-end data sources. FES provides the server-side infrastructure and the client-side APIs needed to build these “data rich applications”. This article focuses on making the shift to Data Services as a programming model. For more information on FES, read the [[Flex_Enterprise_Services:overview | Flex Enterprise Services Overview]] on Macromedia Labs.+One of the most exciting new features of Flex Data Services (FDS) is the ability to easily manage data synchronization between Flex clients and backend services and data. In Flex applications a version of the application data exists on the client tier in a structured, meaningful way. This allows data manipulation to be performed on the client tier, but it requires that the changes to that data be synchronized with back-end data sources. FDS provides the server-side infrastructure and the client-side APIs needed to build these “data rich applications”. This article focuses on making the shift to Data Management Services as a programming model. For more information on FDS, read the [[Flex_Enterprise_Services:overview | Flex Data Services Overview]] on Adobe Labs.
-Before all of the persistence options available today (CMP, Hibernate, JDO, etc) existed, data was typically managed though RPC-style operations via JDBC. This led to complex and difficult to maintain code. Developers felt this pain and numerous persistence frameworks were created to address this problem. Early RIA developers have also begun to feel the pain of RPC-style data management. Data Services represent the first real end-to-end persistence framework for Flex Applications, allowing code to be simpler and more organized.+Before all of the persistence options available today (CMP, Hibernate, JDO, etc) existed, data was typically managed though RPC-style operations via JDBC. This led to complex and difficult to maintain code. Developers felt this pain and numerous persistence frameworks were created to address this problem. Early RIA developers have also begun to feel the pain of RPC-style data management. Data Management Services represent the first real end-to-end persistence framework for Flex Applications, allowing code to be simpler and more organized.
-All frameworks have associated patterns which help developers to most effectively use the framework. Data Services is no different. In fact Data Services display many features which will appear familiar to developers used to Model View Controller (MVC) design patterns. Applications typically rely on a set of objects and collections of objects which act as the application’s model. The display components which correspond to the view can then use Data Binding to connect to the model data. The framework ensures that this data and the presentation components remain in sync as the data changes state. +All frameworks have associated patterns which help developers to most effectively use the framework. Data Management Services is no different. In fact Data Managment Services display many features which will appear familiar to developers used to Model View Controller (MVC) design patterns. Applications typically rely on a set of objects and collections of objects which act as the application’s model. The display components which correspond to the view can then use Data Binding to connect to the model data. The framework ensures that this data and the presentation components remain in sync as the data changes state.
'''Refactoring Restaurant Finder – Data Retrieval''' '''Refactoring Restaurant Finder – Data Retrieval'''
-This article will use the Restaurant Finder application for code examples of RPC style data management. Data management can be grouped into 4 basic operations; create, retrieve, update, and delete (CRUD). We will look at the code used to implement each of these operations and discuss the limitations of the implementation and how Data Services can be used to improve the implementation.+This article will use the Restaurant Finder application for code examples of RPC style data management. Data management can be grouped into 4 basic operations; create, retrieve, update, and delete (CRUD). We will look at the code used to implement each of these operations and discuss the limitations of the implementation and how Data Management Services can be used to improve the implementation.
Retrieve is the most fundamental part of any application involving data. Here is how the Restaurant Finder application retrieves reviews for a given restaurant: Retrieve is the most fundamental part of any application involving data. Here is how the Restaurant Finder application retrieves reviews for a given restaurant:
Line 32: Line 32:
Another limitation of this implementation is that there is no simple way to handle data preloading. Let’s say that we want to do background loading of the reviews so that when the user navigates to a different restraint that review data is already loaded. The developer is going to need to add complex code to handle the preloading in an efficient manner. Another limitation of this implementation is that there is no simple way to handle data preloading. Let’s say that we want to do background loading of the reviews so that when the user navigates to a different restraint that review data is already loaded. The developer is going to need to add complex code to handle the preloading in an efficient manner.
-When using Data Services if the data set changes the server sends the list of changes to all connected clients “viewing” the changed data set. The data set on each client is then updated. To do background loading of data in Data Services all the developer needs to do is specify paging parameters on the Data Services destination. Using Data Services to get the reviews for a given restaurant may look like:+When using Data Management Services if the data set changes the server sends the list of changes to all connected clients “viewing” the changed data set. The data set on each client is then updated. To do background loading of data in Data Management Services all the developer needs to do is specify paging parameters on the Data Management Services destination. Using Data Management Services to get the reviews for a given restaurant may look like:
private function init():Void private function init():Void
Line 63: Line 63:
Another limitation of RPC-style applications is that the client application needs to track object changes on its own. For instance if changes should be batched and committed all at the same time, then special code must be written to track the objects changes and the types of changes. More complex, error prone code must then be written to handle the commit operation, iterating through the changes. Another limitation of RPC-style applications is that the client application needs to track object changes on its own. For instance if changes should be batched and committed all at the same time, then special code must be written to track the objects changes and the types of changes. More complex, error prone code must then be written to handle the commit operation, iterating through the changes.
-In Data Services changes are made to a managed object(s) and then committed. The changes can be creates, updates, or deletes. If the data is managed by Data Services, the changes will be tracked and upon commit sent to the server. If the server encounters an error when committing the changes, the client is able to easily rollback the changes, or modify the data and commit again. Here is what the above add review code may look like in Data Services code (assuming autoCommit is set to false):+In Data Management Services changes are made to a managed object(s) and then committed. The changes can be creates, updates, or deletes. If the data is managed by Data Management Services, the changes will be tracked and upon commit sent to the server. If the server encounters an error when committing the changes, the client is able to easily rollback the changes, or modify the data and commit again. Here is what the above add review code may look like in Data Management Services code (assuming autoCommit is set to false):
private function createReview():Void private function createReview():Void
Line 90: Line 90:
} }
-An important part of Data Services is resolving conflicts. Any commit can result in a conflict if the object being committed is not in sync with the server or if changes have been made by other clients during the editing process. Data Services detects these conflicts automatically but resolving the conflicts must be handled by the application using the appropriate logic. In the code below the conflictHandler function is being called when a conflict occurs. The code iterates through the conflicts and in this instance automatically accepts the server version of the object and prompts the user to fix the problem. In some cases this implementation would be sufficient, while in others the application may want to automatically accept the client’s changes, or perhaps ask the user which version (client or server) should be accepted.+An important part of Data Management Services is resolving conflicts. Any commit can result in a conflict if the object being committed is not in sync with the server or if changes have been made by other clients during the editing process. Data Management Services detects these conflicts automatically but resolving the conflicts must be handled by the application using the appropriate logic. In the code below the conflictHandler function is being called when a conflict occurs. The code iterates through the conflicts and in this instance automatically accepts the server version of the object and prompts the user to fix the problem. In some cases this implementation would be sufficient, while in others the application may want to automatically accept the client’s changes, or perhaps ask the user which version (client or server) should be accepted.
private function init():Void private function init():Void
Line 111: Line 111:
'''Conclusion''' '''Conclusion'''
-In simple examples like the Restaurant Finder, Data Services can help simplify the code somewhat. However, as applications grow in complexity RPC-style code becomes more and more difficult to manage. With objects managed by Data Services data retrieval is no longer limited to a request-response model. A data set can be retrieved and automatically kept in sync allowing create, update, and delete operations to be performed, batched and then committed. Low level concerns like data locking, flagging changes, handling conflicts and concurrency issues are all built into the framework allowing data retrieval and manipulation code to focus exclusively on those functions.+In simple examples like the Restaurant Finder, Data Management Services can help simplify the code somewhat. However, as applications grow in complexity RPC-style code becomes more and more difficult to manage. With objects managed by Data Management Services data retrieval is no longer limited to a request-response model. A data set can be retrieved and automatically kept in sync allowing create, update, and delete operations to be performed, batched and then committed. Low level concerns like data locking, flagging changes, handling conflicts and concurrency issues are all built into the framework allowing data retrieval and manipulation code to focus exclusively on those functions.
-Data Services overcomes many of the limitations in RPC-style data management by providing standard client and server APIs for data retrieval and manipulation. These APIs allow CRUD code to be simpler, more organized and more maintainable. For most Flex applications the transition to Data Services should be simple. For new applications to utilize Data Services the biggest hurdle will be in learning to design the application around managed data objects. However, applications designed to use Data Services receive all the maintenance benefits of now-traditional persistence frameworks such as Hibernate in addition to gaining access to an entirely new programming model specifically targeted at simplifying Flex application development.+Data Services overcomes many of the limitations in RPC-style data management by providing standard client and server APIs for data retrieval and manipulation. These APIs allow CRUD code to be simpler, more organized and more maintainable. For most Flex applications the transition to Data Services should be simple. For new applications to utilize Data Management Services the biggest hurdle will be in learning to design the application around managed data objects. However, applications designed to use Data Management Services receive all the maintenance benefits of now-traditional persistence frameworks such as Hibernate in addition to gaining access to an entirely new programming model specifically targeted at simplifying Flex application development.

item.title: Flex:Accessing Data
item.description:
/* Messaging Services */

Revision as of 01:36, 21 Mar 2006 Current revision
Line 1: Line 1:
-This article contains important information about how to access data from applications built with the Flex Framework 2.0 and Flex Builder 2.0.+This article contains important information about how to access data from applications built with the Flex framework and Flex Builder 2.0.
== Introduction == == Introduction ==
Line 8: Line 8:
== RPC services == == RPC services ==
-Flex provides three ways of sending and receiving data using remote procedure calls (RPC). These are the HTTPService, WebService, and RemoteObject tags. The first two can be used by any application built in Flex Builder 2. The RemoteObject tag requires Flex Enterprise Services to process the RemoteObject requests.+Flex provides three ways of sending and receiving data using remote procedure calls (RPC). These are the HTTPService, WebService, and RemoteObject tags. The first two can be used by any application built in Flex Builder 2. The RemoteObject tag requires Flex Data Services to process the RemoteObject requests.
* '''HTTPService''' lets you send HTTP GET and POST requests from a Flex application. You can use HTTPService to load an XML file from a URL, or to request JavaServer Pages (JSPs), servlets, and ASP pages that serve data to your application. * '''HTTPService''' lets you send HTTP GET and POST requests from a Flex application. You can use HTTPService to load an XML file from a URL, or to request JavaServer Pages (JSPs), servlets, and ASP pages that serve data to your application.
Line 28: Line 28:
=== Setting up your own proxy === === Setting up your own proxy ===
-Another way to manage Flash Player security is to use a proxy. Flex Enterprise Services provides a complete proxy management system for Flex applications. You can also create a simple proxy service using a web scripting language such as ColdFusion, JSP, PHP, or ASP. +Another way to manage Flash Player security is to use a proxy. Flex Data Services provides a complete proxy management system for Flex applications. You can also create a simple proxy service using a web scripting language such as ColdFusion, JSP, PHP, or ASP.
All the proxy service needs to do is pass requests to the remote service, and pass responses from the remote service back to Flash Player. For more information about creating your own proxy, see http://www.macromedia.com/cfusion/knowledgebase/index.cfm?id=tn_16520#proxy. All the proxy service needs to do is pass requests to the remote service, and pass responses from the remote service back to Flash Player. For more information about creating your own proxy, see http://www.macromedia.com/cfusion/knowledgebase/index.cfm?id=tn_16520#proxy.
Line 53: Line 53:
# If your proxy server is not your local machine, you will need to copy the contents of the bin directory to your server before running or debugging your program. # If your proxy server is not your local machine, you will need to copy the contents of the bin directory to your server before running or debugging your program.
-== Data Services ==+== Data Managment Services ==
-Data Services included with Flex Enterprise Services, provides a data-centric programming model that automates data synchronization between application tiers, enables real-time data updates, data replication, and occasionally connected application services, and provides integration with data sources through adapters. This feature lets you create applications that work with distributed data, and lets you manage large collections of data and nested data relationships, such as one-to-one and one-to-many relationships. When using Data Services, SWF files are typically served from the same server where the Flex Enterprise Services are deployed. As a result, the Flex application can communicate directly with the Flex server without the need for additional proxies or crossdomain files. +Data Management Services included with Flex Data Services, provides a data-centric programming model that automates data synchronization between application tiers, enables real-time data updates, data replication, and occasionally connected application services, and provides integration with data sources through adapters. This feature lets you create applications that work with distributed data, and lets you manage large collections of data and nested data relationships, such as one-to-one and one-to-many relationships. When using Data Management Services, SWF files are typically served from the same server where the Flex Data Services are deployed. As a result, the Flex application can communicate directly with the Flex server without the need for additional proxies or crossdomain files.
-For more details on Data Services, see: http://labs.macromedia.com/wiki/index.php/Flex_Enterprise_Services:Data_Services+[[Flex_Enterprise_Services:Data_Services|See more details on Data Services]].
== Messaging Services == == Messaging Services ==
-The publish-subscribe messaging feature, included with Flex Enterprise Services, provides messaging services for collaborative and real-time applications. This feature lets you create applications that can send messages to and receive messages from other applications, including Flex applications and Java Message Service (JMS) applications. Messages can contain text or objects.+The publish-subscribe messaging feature, included with Flex Data Services, provides messaging services for collaborative and real-time applications. This feature lets you create applications that can send messages to and receive messages from other applications, including Flex applications and Java Message Service (JMS) applications. Messages can contain text or objects.
-For more information about data services and messaging, check out:+[[Flex_Enterprise_Services|Check out more information about Flex Data Services and messaging]].
-http://labs.macromedia.com/wiki/index.php/Flex_Enterprise_Services +
-You can also read about how to get started in the Flex Enterprise Services section of Macromedia Labs. http://labs.macromedia.com/technologies/flexenterprise_services2/+You can also read about how to get started in the Flex Data Services section of Adobe Labs. http://labs.macromedia.com/technologies/flexenterprise_services2/

item.title: Flex Framework:Migrating
item.description:
Revision as of 01:29, 21 Mar 2006 Current revision
Line 1: Line 1:
-This document describes Migrating Flex 1.x Applications to be compatible with the Flex 2.0 Framework.+This document describes Migrating Flex 1.x Applications to be compatible with the Flex framework.
== Overview of Migration == == Overview of Migration ==
-Flex is undergoing a dramatic change. All your apps — from the smallest Hello web example to that enterprise data modeling app you've been tinkering with in your spare time — are about to need a little love and attention to make them play nice with the Flex 2.0 Framework. Before you update your apps, though, keep the following things in mind:+Flex is undergoing a dramatic change. All your apps — from the smallest Hello web example to that enterprise data modeling app you've been tinkering with in your spare time — are about to need a little love and attention to make them play nice with the Flex framework. Before you update your apps, though, keep the following things in mind:
#You don't have to migrate unless you want to. Flex 1.x applications continue to run under the new Flash Player. #You don't have to migrate unless you want to. Flex 1.x applications continue to run under the new Flash Player.
Line 10: Line 10:
=== Architecture === === Architecture ===
-Don't think of Flex as a web application or a presentation server any more. It isn't. Flex 2.0 is a lot more. And the heart of Flex 2.0 is the framework. [[Flex_Framework|Flex Framework 2.0]], as it's officially called, is a programming model, a set of components and class libraries that make building Rich Internet Applications easy. This framework is included with the all new Eclipse-based [[Flex_Builder|Flex Builder 2.0 IDE]]. There is still a server component in the Flex 2.0 product line, Flex Enterprise Services 2.0, but its capabilities are focused around messaging and enterprise data services. +Don't think of Flex as a web application or a presentation server any more. It isn't. Flex 2.0 is a lot more. And the heart of Flex 2.0 is the framework. The [[Flex_Framework|Flex framework]], as it's officially called, is a programming model, a set of components and class libraries that make building rich Internet applications easy. This framework is included with the all new Eclipse-based [[Flex_Builder|Flex Builder 2.0 IDE]]. There is still a server component in the Flex 2.0 product line, Flex Data Services 2.0, but its capabilities are focused around messaging and enterprise data services.
-You read that right. With Flex 2.0 you won’t need to purchase a server to build applications that use Flex Framework. This might take a little getting used to, because you've been putting MXML files into a web directory and requesting them with a browser to see how they run. Well, you don't need to do that anymore. What you do now is either run them from within Flex Builder 2.0 or use the command-line compiler mxmlc.+You read that right. With Flex 2.0 you won’t need to purchase a server to build applications that use the Flex framework. This might take a little getting used to, because you've been putting MXML files into a web directory and requesting them with a browser to see how they run. Well, you don't need to do that anymore. What you do now is either run them from within Flex Builder 2.0 or use the command-line compiler mxmlc.
The end result is a SWF file that you deploy inside your favorite web server. The end result is a SWF file that you deploy inside your favorite web server.
Line 19: Line 19:
The biggest news is that the underlying language is all grown up — real OO, real type safety, real XML object manipulation. You can read about all the new [[ActionScript_3:overview#Language_Features|features of ActionScript 3]] or jump right into the [http://www.macromedia.com/go/flex2_apiref language reference] to see the new (and improved) class libraries. There's also a [[ActionScript_3:Learning_Tips|Tips for Learning ActionScript 3.0]] and even a list of [http://www.macromedia.com/go/AS2toAS3 complete list of methods that have changed]. The biggest news is that the underlying language is all grown up — real OO, real type safety, real XML object manipulation. You can read about all the new [[ActionScript_3:overview#Language_Features|features of ActionScript 3]] or jump right into the [http://www.macromedia.com/go/flex2_apiref language reference] to see the new (and improved) class libraries. There's also a [[ActionScript_3:Learning_Tips|Tips for Learning ActionScript 3.0]] and even a list of [http://www.macromedia.com/go/AS2toAS3 complete list of methods that have changed].
-=== Data Services ===+=== Data Management Services ===
-Data Services included with Flex Enterprise Services, provides a data-centric programming model that automates data synchronization between application tiers, enables real-time data updates, data replication, and occasionally connected application services, and provides integration with data sources through adapters. This feature lets you create applications that work with distributed data, and lets you manage large collections of data and nested data relationships, such as one-to-one and one-to-many relationships. When using Data Services, SWF files are typically served from the same server where the Flex Enterprise Services are deployed. As a result, the Flex application can communicate directly with the Flex server without the need for additional proxies or crossdomain files. +Data Management Services included with Flex Data Services, provides a data-centric programming model that automates data synchronization between application tiers, enables real-time data updates, data replication, and occasionally connected application services, and provides integration with data sources through adapters. This feature lets you create applications that work with distributed data, and lets you manage large collections of data and nested data relationships, such as one-to-one and one-to-many relationships. When using Data Managment Services, SWF files are typically served from the same server where the Flex Data Services are deployed. As a result, the Flex application can communicate directly with the Flex server without the need for additional proxies or crossdomain files.
-For more details on Data Services, see: http://labs.macromedia.com/wiki/index.php/Flex_Enterprise_Services:Data_Services +See more details on [[Flex_Enterprise_Services:Data_Services|Data Management Services]].
Please also check out [[Flex:Accessing_Data|this article on accessing data]] for more info. Please also check out [[Flex:Accessing_Data|this article on accessing data]] for more info.
